canonical_explanation.text:
Body fluids include blood, lymph (tissue fluid) and interstitial fluid, which together constitute the internal transport system of the body. Blood is a connective tissue consisting of plasma (55%) and formed elements (45%) — red blood corpuscles (RBCs/erythrocytes), white blood corpuscles (WBCs/leucocytes) and platelets (thrombocytes). Plasma contains water (90-92%), proteins (albumins, globulins, fibrinogen), glucose, amino acids, lipids, hormones, electrolytes and dissolved gases. RBCs are biconcave, enucleated discs containing haemoglobin. WBCs are of two types: granulocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils) and agranulocytes (lymphocytes, monocytes). Blood groups (ABO and Rh) are determined by surface antigens on RBCs. Blood coagulation involves a cascade of reactions converting fibrinogen to fibrin threads that seal the wound.

The human heart is a four-chambered organ (two atria and two ventricles) enclosed in a pericardial sac. The SA node (sino-atrial node), located in the right atrium, acts as the natural pacemaker. The cardiac cycle lasts about 0.8 seconds and includes atrial systole, ventricular systole and joint diastole. Cardiac output = stroke volume x heart rate (~70 mL x 72 beats/min = ~5040 mL/min). The electrocardiogram (ECG) records the electrical activity of the heart: P wave (atrial depolarisation), QRS complex (ventricular depolarisation) and T wave (ventricular repolarisation). Humans have a double circulation system — pulmonary (heart-lungs-heart) and systemic (heart-body-heart). The lymphatic system returns interstitial fluid to the blood. Common cardiovascular disorders include hypertension, coronary artery disease, angina pectoris and heart failure.
rules: Blood plasma constitutes about 55% of blood volume and contains water (90-92%), proteins (albumin, globulin, fibrinogen), glucose, amino acids and electrolytes.
RBCs are biconcave, enucleated (in mammals) discs with a lifespan of about 120 days; they are formed in the red bone marrow and destroyed in the spleen.

ABO blood grouping is based on the presence of antigens A and B on RBC surface: Type A (antigen A), Type B (antigen B), Type AB (both antigens, universal recipient), Type O (no antigens, universal donor).
Rh factor: Rh-positive individuals have Rh antigen on their RBCs; erythroblastosis foetalis occurs when an Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive foetus in subsequent pregnancies.
The coagulation cascade involves conversion of prothrombin to thrombin (by thromboplastin and Ca2+), and thrombin converts fibrinogen to fibrin, which forms the clot.
The SA node (pacemaker) is located in the right atrium and generates impulses that initiate each heartbeat at ~72 beats per minute.
The conduction system of the heart: SA node → AV node → Bundle of His → Purkinje fibres.
The cardiac cycle (0.8 s) consists of atrial systole (0.1 s), ventricular systole (0.3 s) and joint diastole (0.4 s).
ECG waves: P wave = atrial depolarisation, QRS complex = ventricular depolarisation, T wave = ventricular repolarisation.
Cardiac output = Stroke volume × Heart rate; normal cardiac output is approximately 5 litres per minute.

Double circulation: Pulmonary circuit (right ventricle → lungs → left atrium) carries deoxygenated blood to lungs; systemic circuit (left ventricle → body → right atrium) distributes oxygenated blood.
Hypertension is defined as persistently high blood pressure (above 140/90 mmHg); atherosclerosis is the deposition of fatty plaques on arterial walls.

questions.question_text: Plasma constitutes approximately what percentage of blood volume?
questions.explanation_correct: Plasma constitutes approximately 55% of the total blood volume. It is a straw-coloured, slightly alkaline fluid containing water (90-92%), proteins, glucose, amino acids, lipids, hormones, electrolytes and dissolved gases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formed elements (RBCs, WBCs, platelets) make up about 45% of blood volume. Plasma is 55%, not 25%, 45% or 75%.

questions.question_text: Which of the following plasma proteins is involved in blood clotting?
questions.explanation_correct: Fibrinogen is a plasma protein that plays a key role in blood clotting. During coagulation, thrombin converts fibrinogen into insoluble fibrin threads, which form a mesh to trap blood cells and seal the wound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Albumin helps maintain osmotic balance. Globulins include antibodies and transport proteins. Haemoglobin is found inside RBCs, not in plasma.

questions.question_text: Red blood corpuscles (RBCs) in humans are:
questions.explanation_correct: Mature human RBCs are enucleated (without nucleus) and biconcave disc-shaped. The biconcave shape increases the surface area for gas exchange, and the absence of a nucleus allows more space for haemoglobin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mature mammalian RBCs lose their nucleus during development. They are biconcave discs, not spherical. Some non-mammalian vertebrates have nucleated RBCs.

questions.question_text: The average lifespan of a human RBC is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The average lifespan of a human RBC is approximately 120 days (about 4 months). After this, old and damaged RBCs are destroyed in the spleen (also called the 'graveyard of RBCs') and the liver.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lifespan is 120 days, not 30, 60 or 365 days. After 120 days, RBCs become fragile and are removed from circulation.

questions.question_text: A person with blood group AB has:

options.text: antigen A on RBCs and antibody b in plasma.
both antigens A and B on RBCs and no antibodies in plasma.
no antigens on RBCs and both antibodies a and b in plasma.
antigen B on RBCs and antibody a in plasma.

questions.explanation_correct: A person with blood group AB has both antigen A and antigen B on the surface of their RBCs and neither anti-A nor anti-B antibodies in their plasma. This makes them universal recipients — they can receive blood from any ABO group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Having only antigen A with antibody b is blood group A. Having no antigens with both antibodies is blood group O. Having antigen B with antibody a is blood group B.

questions.question_text: A person with blood group O is called a 'universal donor' because:

options.text: their RBCs have both A and B antigens.
their RBCs lack both A and B antigens, so they will not be agglutinated by the recipient's antibodies.
they can receive blood from any blood group.

questions.explanation_correct: Blood group O individuals are universal donors because their RBCs have neither antigen A nor antigen B on their surface. Therefore, their RBCs will not be agglutinated (clumped) by anti-A or anti-B antibodies in any recipient's plasma.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both antigens are present in AB, not O. O group has both antibodies (a and b) in plasma. Universal recipient is AB, not O.

questions.question_text: Erythroblastosis foetalis can occur when:

options.text: an Rh-positive mother carries an Rh-negative foetus.
an Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive foetus (usually in second or subsequent pregnancies).

questions.explanation_correct: Erythroblastosis foetalis occurs when an Rh-negative mother is sensitised by carrying an Rh-positive foetus. During the first pregnancy, the mother develops anti-Rh antibodies. In subsequent pregnancies with Rh-positive foetuses, these antibodies cross the placenta and destroy foetal RBCs, causing haemolytic disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the mother is Rh-positive, no anti-Rh antibodies are formed regardless of the foetus's Rh status. If both parents are Rh-negative, the foetus will also be Rh-negative, so no conflict occurs.

questions.question_text: The process of blood clotting involves the following steps. Which is the correct sequence?

options.text: Injury → Thromboplastin release → Prothrombin → Thrombin → Fibrinogen → Fibrin → Clot

questions.explanation_correct: Upon injury, platelets and damaged tissues release thromboplastin (and other factors). In the presence of Ca2+, thromboplastin helps convert prothrombin (inactive) to thrombin (active enzyme). Thrombin then converts the soluble fibrinogen into insoluble fibrin threads, which form a mesh trapping blood cells to form a clot.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cascade must start with injury and release of thromboplastin. Prothrombin is converted to thrombin first, and then fibrinogen to fibrin. The reverse sequences are incorrect.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about formed elements of blood:
(i) Neutrophils are the most abundant WBCs.
(ii) Eosinophils are associated with allergic reactions.
(iii) Basophils release histamine and heparin.
(iv) Monocytes are granulocytes.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct. Neutrophils are the most abundant WBCs (60-65%). Eosinophils are associated with allergic reactions and defence against parasites. Basophils release histamine (involved in inflammation) and heparin (anticoagulant). Statement (iv) is incorrect — monocytes are agranulocytes, not granulocytes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Monocytes are agranulocytes (along with lymphocytes). Granulocytes include neutrophils, eosinophils and basophils.

questions.question_text:
Match the blood group with its antigens and antibodies:
(a) Blood Group A - (i) No antigens, Anti-A and Anti-B antibodies
(b) Blood Group B - (ii) Antigen A, Anti-B antibodies
(c) Blood Group AB - (iii) Antigen B, Anti-A antibodies
(d) Blood Group O - (iv) Antigens A and B, No antibodies
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: Blood Group A: Antigen A, Anti-B antibodies. Blood Group B: Antigen B, Anti-A antibodies. Blood Group AB: Both antigens A and B, no antibodies (universal recipient). Blood Group O: No antigens, both Anti-A and Anti-B antibodies (universal donor).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each blood group has a specific combination of antigens on RBCs and antibodies in plasma. The ABO system follows the rule that antibodies are present against the absent antigens.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Thrombocytes (platelets) are cell fragments and not true cells.
Reason (R): Platelets are formed by fragmentation of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow and lack a nucleus.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Platelets (thrombocytes) are not complete cells — they are cytoplasmic fragments derived from large cells called megakaryocytes in the red bone marrow. They lack a nucleus, which is why they are classified as cell fragments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason accurately explains why platelets are cell fragments — they arise from fragmentation of megakaryocytes and lack a nucleus.

questions.question_text: WBCs that produce antibodies are:
questions.explanation_correct: B-lymphocytes (a type of WBC) are responsible for the production of antibodies. When activated by an antigen, B-lymphocytes differentiate into plasma cells that secrete specific antibodies to neutralise the pathogen. This is part of the humoral (antibody-mediated) immune response.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutrophils are phagocytic cells. Monocytes differentiate into macrophages for phagocytosis. Basophils release histamine and heparin. None of these directly produce antibodies.

questions.question_text: The site of formation of RBCs in adults is the:
questions.explanation_correct: In adults, RBCs are produced in the red bone marrow (a process called erythropoiesis). The red bone marrow is found in flat bones such as the sternum, ribs, hip bones and vertebrae. In the foetus, the liver and spleen also participate in RBC formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The liver and spleen produce RBCs during foetal development but not in adults. Lymph nodes produce lymphocytes, not RBCs.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of blood?
questions.explanation_correct: Blood transports O2 and nutrients, provides immunity (through WBCs and antibodies), helps regulate body temperature (through redistribution of heat) and is involved in clotting. Secretion of digestive enzymes is the function of digestive glands, not blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transport of oxygen, defence against infections and temperature regulation are all important functions of blood.

questions.question_text: The spleen is often referred to as the 'graveyard of RBCs' because:

options.text: old and damaged RBCs are destroyed in the spleen.

questions.explanation_correct: The spleen is called the graveyard of RBCs because old, worn-out and damaged red blood cells (after their ~120 day lifespan) are destroyed and removed from circulation by macrophages in the spleen. The haemoglobin is broken down and its components are recycled.
questions.explanation_incorrect: RBC production in adults occurs in the red bone marrow, not the spleen. Lymph filtration is done by lymph nodes.

questions.question_text: Serum differs from plasma in that serum:

options.text: lacks fibrinogen and other clotting factors.
has a higher percentage of water.

questions.explanation_correct: Serum is blood plasma from which clotting factors (especially fibrinogen) have been removed. It is the fluid that separates from blood after coagulation. Plasma minus clotting factors = Serum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Serum lacks clotting factors (that is the key difference). WBC and water content are not the distinguishing features between plasma and serum.

questions.question_text: The human heart has:

options.text: two chambers — one atrium and one ventricle.
three chambers — two atria and one ventricle.
four chambers — two atria and two ventricles.
four chambers — one atrium and three ventricles.

questions.explanation_correct: The human heart has four chambers: two upper chambers called atria (right and left atrium) and two lower chambers called ventricles (right and left ventricle). The atria receive blood and the ventricles pump blood out of the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two-chambered hearts are found in fish, three-chambered in amphibians. The human (mammalian) heart is four-chambered with two atria and two ventricles.

questions.question_text: The natural pacemaker of the heart is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The SA node (sino-atrial node), located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava, acts as the natural pacemaker of the heart. It generates electrical impulses at a rate of about 72 per minute, initiating each heartbeat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The AV node, Bundle of His and Purkinje fibres are part of the cardiac conduction system but they relay impulses generated by the SA node. They do not initiate the heartbeat.

questions.question_text: The duration of one complete cardiac cycle is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: One complete cardiac cycle lasts approximately 0.8 seconds at a heart rate of 72 beats per minute. It consists of atrial systole (0.1 s), ventricular systole (0.3 s) and joint diastole (0.4 s).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0.4 s is the duration of joint diastole alone. 1.2 s and 2.0 s are too long for a normal cardiac cycle at 72 bpm.

questions.question_text: In the cardiac cycle, the correct sequence of events is:

options.text: Ventricular systole → Atrial systole → Joint diastole
Atrial systole → Ventricular systole → Joint diastole
Joint diastole → Ventricular systole → Atrial systole
Atrial systole → Joint diastole → Ventricular systole

questions.explanation_correct: The cardiac cycle begins with atrial systole (contraction of both atria, pushing blood into ventricles for 0.1 s), followed by ventricular systole (contraction of both ventricles, pumping blood into arteries for 0.3 s), and then joint diastole (relaxation of all chambers for 0.4 s).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atrial systole must precede ventricular systole to fill the ventricles before they contract. Joint diastole follows ventricular systole to allow the chambers to refill.

questions.question_text: The P wave in an ECG represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The P wave in an ECG represents atrial depolarisation — the electrical impulse spreading across both atria from the SA node, causing atrial contraction (atrial systole).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ventricular depolarisation is represented by the QRS complex. Ventricular repolarisation is represented by the T wave. Atrial repolarisation is masked by the QRS complex.

questions.question_text: The QRS complex in an ECG represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The QRS complex represents ventricular depolarisation — the spread of electrical impulse through the ventricles via the Bundle of His and Purkinje fibres, causing ventricular contraction (ventricular systole).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atrial depolarisation is the P wave. Ventricular repolarisation is the T wave. Atrial repolarisation occurs during the QRS complex but is masked by the larger ventricular signal.

questions.question_text: The cardiac output of a person with a stroke volume of 70 mL and a heart rate of 72 beats per minute is:
questions.explanation_correct: Cardiac output = Stroke volume x Heart rate = 70 mL x 72 beats/min = 5040 mL/min (approximately 5 litres per minute). This represents the volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per minute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The calculation is 70 x 72 = 5040 mL/min. Other values would result from using incorrect stroke volume or heart rate figures.

questions.question_text: The correct sequence of cardiac conduction system is:

options.text: SA node → Bundle of His → AV node → Purkinje fibres
AV node → SA node → Bundle of His → Purkinje fibres
SA node → AV node → Bundle of His → Purkinje fibres
Purkinje fibres → Bundle of His → AV node → SA node

questions.explanation_correct: The cardiac conduction pathway is: SA node (pacemaker, generates impulse) → AV node (delays impulse slightly to allow atrial emptying) → Bundle of His (transmits impulse to ventricles) → Purkinje fibres (distribute impulse throughout ventricular walls).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The SA node always initiates the impulse. The AV node receives from SA node, not the other way. The sequence cannot begin at Bundle of His or Purkinje fibres.

questions.question_text:
Match the following ECG waves with their significance:
(a) P wave - (i) Ventricular repolarisation
(b) QRS complex - (ii) Atrial depolarisation
(c) T wave - (iii) Ventricular depolarisation
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: P wave represents atrial depolarisation (electrical activation of atria). QRS complex represents ventricular depolarisation (electrical activation of ventricles). T wave represents ventricular repolarisation (electrical recovery of ventricles).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct sequence of ECG interpretation is: P = atrial depolarisation, QRS = ventricular depolarisation, T = ventricular repolarisation.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): The SA node is called the pacemaker of the heart.
Reason (R): The SA node has the highest rate of spontaneous depolarisation and generates impulses that set the rhythm for the entire heart.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion. The SA node generates action potentials at the highest intrinsic rate (~72/min) compared to the AV node (~40-60/min) or Purkinje fibres (~20-40/min). This makes it the dominant pacemaker, dictating the rhythm for the entire heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason accurately explains why the SA node acts as the pacemaker — its highest rate of spontaneous depolarisation overrides all other potential pacemaker sites.

questions.question_text: The valves that prevent backflow of blood from the ventricles to the atria are called:
questions.explanation_correct: The atrioventricular (AV) valves prevent the backflow of blood from ventricles to atria. The tricuspid valve is between the right atrium and right ventricle (3 cusps), and the bicuspid (mitral) valve is between the left atrium and left ventricle (2 cusps).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary) prevent backflow from arteries into ventricles, not from ventricles to atria.

questions.question_text: The T wave in an ECG represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The T wave represents ventricular repolarisation — the recovery of the ventricular myocardium from its depolarised state back to the resting potential, preparing for the next contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atrial depolarisation is the P wave. Ventricular depolarisation is the QRS complex. Atrial repolarisation is masked within the QRS complex.

questions.question_text: The first heart sound (lub) is produced by the:

options.text: closure of semilunar valves at the beginning of ventricular diastole.
closure of atrioventricular valves at the beginning of ventricular systole.
opening of atrioventricular valves during atrial systole.
opening of semilunar valves during ventricular systole.

questions.explanation_correct: The first heart sound ('lub') is produced by the closure of the atrioventricular valves (tricuspid and bicuspid) at the beginning of ventricular systole. This closure prevents blood from flowing back into the atria when the ventricles contract.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Closure of semilunar valves produces the second heart sound ('dub'). Opening of valves does not produce the characteristic heart sounds.

questions.question_text: During joint diastole of the cardiac cycle:

options.text: both atria and ventricles are relaxed, and blood flows from veins into the atria and then into ventricles.
blood is pumped into the aorta and pulmonary artery.

questions.explanation_correct: During joint diastole (lasting 0.4 s), both the atria and ventricles are in a relaxed state. Blood from the veins (superior and inferior vena cava, and pulmonary veins) flows passively into the atria and then through the open AV valves into the ventricles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: During joint diastole, both chambers are relaxed. Blood pumping into arteries occurs during ventricular systole, not diastole.

questions.question_text: The heart is enclosed in a double-layered membranous sac called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The heart is enclosed in a double-layered membranous sac called the pericardium. The pericardial fluid between the two layers reduces friction during heartbeats and protects the heart from mechanical shocks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pleural membrane surrounds the lungs. The peritoneum lines the abdominal cavity. The meninges surround the brain and spinal cord.

questions.question_text: The left ventricle has a thicker wall than the right ventricle because:

options.text: it receives blood from both lungs.
it pumps blood to the entire body (systemic circulation) against higher resistance.

questions.explanation_correct: The left ventricle has a much thicker muscular wall (about 3 times thicker) than the right ventricle because it pumps oxygenated blood to the entire body through the systemic circulation, which requires generating much higher pressure to overcome the greater resistance of the systemic circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The left ventricle receives oxygenated blood from the lungs (not deoxygenated). Both ventricles have the same number of valves. The number of blood sources is not the reason for wall thickness.

questions.question_text: Double circulation means that blood passes through the heart:

options.text: once in each complete circuit of the body.
twice in each complete circuit — once through pulmonary and once through systemic circulation.
only through the right side of the heart.
only through the left side of the heart.

questions.explanation_correct: In double circulation, blood passes through the heart twice during one complete circuit. First, deoxygenated blood goes from the heart to the lungs and back (pulmonary circulation). Then, oxygenated blood goes from the heart to the body and back (systemic circulation). This ensures efficient oxygenation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood passing through the heart only once would be single circulation (as in fish). Double circulation involves both pulmonary and systemic circuits, using both sides of the heart.

questions.question_text: In the pulmonary circulation, the pulmonary artery carries:

options.text: oxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.
deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.
oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
deoxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.

questions.explanation_correct: The pulmonary artery is unique in that it carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs for oxygenation. It is the only artery in the body that carries deoxygenated blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygenated blood returns from the lungs to the left atrium through the pulmonary veins. The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart.

questions.question_text: Which blood vessel has the thickest wall and why?

options.text: Veins, because they carry deoxygenated blood.
Capillaries, because they are the site of gas exchange.
Arteries, because they carry blood under high pressure from the heart.
Venules, because they are closest to the capillaries.

questions.explanation_correct: Arteries have the thickest walls with a prominent layer of smooth muscle and elastic tissue. This is because they carry blood at high pressure pumped by the heart and must withstand and regulate this pressure. Veins have thinner walls as blood pressure is lower in them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins have thinner walls with valves. Capillaries have the thinnest walls (one cell thick) for exchange. The thickness relates to pressure, not the type of blood carried.

questions.question_text: Veins have valves to:

options.text: increase the speed of blood flow.
prevent the backward flow of blood, especially against gravity.

questions.explanation_correct: Veins have internal valves that prevent the backward flow (backflow) of blood, especially in the limbs where blood must flow against gravity to return to the heart. These valves, along with skeletal muscle contractions, help push blood towards the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Valves do not speed up blood flow, regulate pressure or facilitate gas exchange. Their sole function is to prevent backflow.

questions.question_text: The lymphatic system helps in:

options.text: returning excess interstitial fluid (tissue fluid) to the blood, absorbing fats, and immune function.

questions.explanation_correct: The lymphatic system has three main functions: (1) draining excess interstitial fluid back into the blood circulation, (2) absorbing fats from the intestine through lacteals, and (3) providing immune defence through lymph nodes which filter pathogens and contain lymphocytes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen transport is done by blood (haemoglobin). RBC production occurs in bone marrow. Hormone secretion is done by endocrine glands.

questions.question_text: Hypertension is defined as a persistent blood pressure higher than:
questions.explanation_correct: Hypertension (high blood pressure) is defined as a persistently elevated blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg or higher. Normal blood pressure is around 120/80 mmHg. Hypertension increases the risk of heart disease, stroke and kidney damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 120/80 mmHg is considered normal blood pressure. 100/60 mmHg may indicate hypotension. While 160/100 mmHg is high, the diagnostic threshold for hypertension is 140/90 mmHg.

questions.question_text: Atherosclerosis is characterised by:

options.text: deposition of cholesterol and fatty plaques on the inner walls of arteries.

questions.explanation_correct: Atherosclerosis is a condition in which cholesterol, fats, calcium and other substances are deposited on the inner lining (intima) of arteries, forming plaques. These plaques narrow the arterial lumen, reduce blood flow and can lead to coronary artery disease and heart attacks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weakening of heart muscles is cardiomyopathy. Inflammation of veins is phlebitis. Excessive platelet production is thrombocytosis.

questions.question_text: Angina pectoris is characterised by:

options.text: chest pain due to inadequate blood supply to the heart muscle.
accumulation of fluid in the lungs.
rupture of blood vessels in the brain.

questions.explanation_correct: Angina pectoris is a condition characterised by acute chest pain due to insufficient blood (and hence oxygen) supply to the heart muscle (myocardium). It is usually caused by narrowing of coronary arteries due to atherosclerosis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fluid in the lungs is pulmonary oedema. Irregular heart rhythm is arrhythmia. Rupture of brain blood vessels is a haemorrhagic stroke.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about double circulation:
(i) Pulmonary circulation involves the right side of the heart.
(ii) Systemic circulation involves the left side of the heart.
(iii) The pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood.
(iv) The aorta carries deoxygenated blood.
Which of the above are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct. Pulmonary circulation: right ventricle → pulmonary artery → lungs → pulmonary veins → left atrium. Systemic circulation: left ventricle → aorta → body → vena cava → right atrium. Pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from lungs to the left atrium. Statement (iv) is incorrect — the aorta carries oxygenated blood, not deoxygenated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The aorta is the largest artery and carries oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to the body. It does not carry deoxygenated blood.

questions.question_text:
Match the following blood vessels with the type of blood they carry:
(a) Pulmonary artery - (i) Oxygenated blood from lungs to heart
(b) Pulmonary vein - (ii) Deoxygenated blood from heart to lungs
(c) Aorta - (iii) Deoxygenated blood from body to heart
(d) Vena cava - (iv) Oxygenated blood from heart to body
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: Pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from heart to lungs. Pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood from lungs to heart. Aorta carries oxygenated blood from heart to body. Vena cava (superior and inferior) carries deoxygenated blood from body to heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary vessels are exceptions to the general rule — pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood and pulmonary vein carries oxygenated blood.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Arteries do not have valves, but veins do.
Reason (R): Blood in arteries flows under high pressure from the heart, which prevents backflow, while blood in veins flows under low pressure and needs valves to prevent backflow.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Arteries carry blood at high pressure, which itself prevents backflow, so valves are not needed. Veins carry blood at lower pressure and rely on valves (and skeletal muscle contractions) to prevent backflow, especially in the limbs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason accurately explains why arteries lack valves and veins have them — it is all about the pressure of blood flow.

questions.question_text: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is caused by:

options.text: infection of the coronary arteries by bacteria.
narrowing of coronary arteries due to deposition of cholesterol and lipid plaques (atherosclerosis).

questions.explanation_correct: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is caused by the narrowing of coronary arteries due to the deposition of cholesterol, fats and other substances (atherosclerotic plaques) on their inner walls. This reduces blood supply to the heart muscle and can lead to angina or heart attack (myocardial infarction).
questions.explanation_incorrect: CAD is not caused by bacterial infection, vein rupture or chamber enlargement. It is primarily a result of atherosclerosis affecting the coronary arteries.

questions.question_text: The hepatic portal system carries blood from the:
questions.explanation_correct: The hepatic portal system (hepatic portal vein) carries nutrient-rich, deoxygenated blood from the digestive organs (intestines, stomach, spleen, pancreas) to the liver. The liver processes, detoxifies and stores nutrients before the blood enters the general circulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hepatic artery carries blood from the heart to the liver. Hepatic veins carry blood from the liver to the heart (via inferior vena cava). The renal portal system (in lower vertebrates) connects kidneys, not the hepatic portal system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the composition of lymph?

options.text: Lymph is similar to blood but lacks RBCs and most plasma proteins.
Lymph contains more RBCs than blood.
Lymph has higher protein concentration than blood plasma.
Lymph is identical in composition to blood.

questions.explanation_correct: Lymph (tissue fluid that enters lymph capillaries) is similar in composition to blood plasma but lacks red blood cells and has a lower concentration of plasma proteins (especially albumin and fibrinogen). It contains WBCs (mainly lymphocytes) and is involved in immune function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lymph lacks RBCs (does not contain more). It has lower protein concentration than plasma. It is not identical to blood — it lacks RBCs, platelets and many plasma proteins.

questions.question_text: If the SA node is damaged, the next structure that can act as the pacemaker is the:
questions.explanation_correct: If the SA node fails, the AV node (atrio-ventricular node) can take over as the secondary pacemaker. The AV node has its own intrinsic rate of about 40-60 beats per minute, which is slower than the SA node's rate of ~72 beats per minute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Bundle of His and Purkinje fibres also have intrinsic rhythmicity, the AV node is the next in line and has a higher intrinsic rate than these structures. The coronary sinus is not part of the conduction system.

questions.question_text: Heart failure (congestive cardiac failure) means that:

options.text: the heart has stopped beating completely.
the heart is not pumping blood efficiently enough to meet the body's needs.
all the coronary arteries are blocked.
the SA node has been destroyed.

questions.explanation_correct: Heart failure (congestive cardiac failure) does not mean the heart has stopped beating. It means the heart is unable to pump blood efficiently enough to meet the body's metabolic demands. This leads to fluid accumulation (congestion) in the lungs and other tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heart failure is not the same as cardiac arrest (complete stopping of the heart). It can occur even with functioning coronary arteries and SA node. It is a progressive condition of pump failure.

questions.question_text: Which WBCs are the most abundant in human blood?
questions.explanation_correct: Neutrophils are the most abundant white blood cells, constituting about 60-65% of the total WBC count. They are phagocytic cells that form the first line of defence against bacterial infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lymphocytes constitute about 20-25% of WBCs. Monocytes make up about 6-8%. Eosinophils constitute about 2-3%. Neutrophils are by far the most numerous.

questions.question_text: A myocardial infarction (heart attack) occurs when:

options.text: the SA node stops generating impulses.
a coronary artery is blocked, cutting off blood supply to a part of the heart muscle.

questions.explanation_correct: A myocardial infarction (heart attack) occurs when a coronary artery is blocked (usually by a blood clot forming on an atherosclerotic plaque). This cuts off the blood supply to a part of the heart muscle (myocardium), causing that area to die due to lack of oxygen and nutrients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SA node failure causes arrhythmia, not a heart attack. Low blood pressure is hypotension. Pericardial fluid loss causes pericarditis-related problems but not a heart attack.
